entry.title: Learning to Count Objects in Images by Lemptisky & Zisserman
entry.content:
Download PDF from here. Paper Citations = 148. Published in Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems in 2010.

Methodology

How to automatically count objects?

Suppose there exists some feature set \(x\) such that its linear transformation maps to the ground-truth (object/crowd) density function i.e. $ F_i(p) = w^T x_p^i $ whereas \(x_p^i\) is feature value at pixel \(p\) in image \(i\).

Then this linear transformation can be learned by solving the following equation \[ w = \underset{w}{\arg\min} \bigg( w^T w + \lambda \sum_{i=1}^{N} dist\big( F_i^0(.), F_i(. \vert w)\big ) \bigg) \]

How to measure \(dist(. , .)\)

Authors have defined a novel distance measure known as MESA: Maximum Excess over SubArrays. Given an image \(I\), the MESA distance \(D_{MESA}\) between two functions \(F_1(p)\) and \(F_2(p)\) is defined as the largest absolute difference between sums of \(F_1(p)\) and \(F_2(p)\) over all box subarrays in \(I\): \[ D_{MESA}( F_1, F_2 ) = \underset{B \in \textbf{B} }{max} \bigg \vert \sum_{p \in B} F_1(p) - \sum_{p \in B} F_2(p) \bigg \vert \] To compute \(D_{MESA}\) they take multiple windows (rectangles) over the image known as box hypothesis B then \(D_{MESA}\) is simply the sum of absolute difference between two windows (rectangles) that differ most.

How to establish ground-truth density?

Since objects (crowd) are discrete in nature i.e.Â there does exists a well defined boundary, in physical world, between two persons then it is easier to individually mark (with a dot) each object separately. But the process of converting this sparse marking into a continuous heat-map is not trivial. Authors have defined the object-density-map as \[ \forall p \in I_i, F_i^0(p) = \sum_{P \in \textbf{P}_i} Normal(p; P, \sigma^2 1_{2 \times 2}) \] Here, \(p\) denotes a pixel, \(Normal(p; P, \sigma^2 1_{2 \times 2})\) denotes a normalized Gaussian kernel evaluated at pixel \(p\) with mean at the user placed dot \(P\) and an isotropic covariance matrix with \(\sigma\) being a small value.
